conclusion: Understanding the scenario of a basketball being dropped from height H and bouncing to height h after an inelastic collision with the ground.
The basketball experiences air resistance proportional to gravitational force, and the task is to find the ratio of post-collision to pre-collision velocity.
Initial conditions: basketball mass m, initial height H, final height h, air resistance λmg, gravitational acceleration g.
Calculate velocity before collision using conservation of energy considering air resistance: v_down = sqrt(2g(H - λH)).
Calculate velocity after collision using conservation of energy considering air resistance: v_up = sqrt(2g(h + λh)).
Express the ratio e = v_up/v_down = sqrt((h(1 + λ))/(H(1 - λ))).
Relate h and H using energy conservation: mgH = mgh + λmg(H + h) + ΔE_collision.
Use coefficient of restitution in energy loss: ΔE_collision can be expressed in terms of e.
